ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to analyze poetry from various time periods
How to read poetry. This was my first poetry class. Also how to write more analytically about poetry.

I learned so much in this class! Nature is such a vast and complex concept, as the class establishes at the very beginning, and poetry is a very beautiful way to understand how it has changed throughout the centuries. The class discussions are very well-guided and always inspires me to look at the texts in a different way.

I learned how to approach complex poetry with a critical eye. This course teaches you to think bout the progression of pastoral and georgic poetry throughout time, and the way in which these literary forms evolve to reflect social, political, and environmental concerns of the time.
Poetry/literature analysis plus some history cnotextualization

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: interesting subject matter 
Weaknesses: discussion sometimes trailed, which is to be expected from a two hour course

I think and improvement could be providing some introductory poetry information to students who have never taken a poetry class before. For example, on canvas, providing a file or something in the syllabus that includes definitions of literary devices used in poetry. Or, summaries of each unit and explaining the background of each period or type of poetry, like romanticism.
This course has a wonderful selection of poems and literary criticism as reading materials, and the discussion sessions are always well-guided. I cant really think of any weaknesses.

I'd say the material was both a strength and a weakness. It was a little challenging to start with the "Classics" (the ancient nature poetry) which was often characteristically dense. That said, it did provide a strong framework for our future discussionsand once we reached the Romantics, the readings felt both engaging and brilliantly selected.
Discussion could be conducted in a bit more of an organized fashion

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes if you find the readings interesting
Yes! Its a beautiful thing to read poetry about nature.

Definitely. I loved how dynamic this class wasthere were English majors, environmental science majors, and other people who found the topic very interesting. I believe whatever someone studies they could learn a lot in this class.
Yes, I recommend this course to students who are curious about poetry and ecocriticism.

Yes, if you're interested in a deep exploration of either depictions of the natural world or poetry. But the course was an intensive dive into nature poetry across time and Prof. Kramnick expects students to engage in rigorous discussion of the texts (in a way that is also very caring and centers student voices).
I had a great time reading the poetry. The readings can feel overwhelming sometimes, as a non-english major
